node.title: The price of carbon hit a record this week. Is Australia cashing in?
node.alt: Fire burns with clouds in the background
node.description: Australian farmers are busy generating carbon credits. They're valuable, but could be worth more.
node.content:
["The price of Australian carbon credit units (ACCU)\u00a0has more than doubled this year, with the spot price reaching a record high of $36.50 this week.", "Carbon credits are mostly sold to large corporates looking to offset their emissions, and around the world, their value is on the rise as countries seek to reach \"net zero\" targets.", "While the value of Australian carbon credits\u00a0has\u00a0broken new ground this week,\u00a0they are still cheap compared\u00a0to other nations.", "The\u00a0carbon price cracked $100 (\u20ac64) a metric\u00a0tonne in Europe last month,\u00a0the UK ETS price is $98 (\u00a354) a tonne and the price has gone over $60 ($NZ65)\u00a0a tonne in New Zealand.", "
So why the price difference?
", "At the moment, Australian farmers and businesses who are generating carbon credits are essentially\u00a0stuck in a voluntary domestic carbon market.", "The federal government might have\u00a0committed to\u00a0net zero emissions by 2050, but it has not legislated its plan, and its Emissions Reduction Fund (ERF) has created a carbon floor price, which most carbon credit producers now try to avoid.", "The latest carbon price through the ERF\u00a0was\u00a0$16.94 per tonne.", "", "
Carbon prices have been on the rise, except the Australian Government's ERF price which remains flat.(Supplied)
", "\"The significant difference between these\u00a0[carbon] markets, is that the EU and New Zealand\u00a0prices are driven by government policy, so the harder the climate target the nation sets for themselves, the higher the carbon price will track, it's a supply and demand dynamic,\" said Tim Moore, RegenCo chief executive officer.", "Dr Moore said the carbon price in Australia would change quickly if Australian companies were legally obliged to offset emissions.\u00a0", "\"But in the absence of a tighter emissions reduction policy from the Australian government, we would expect to see linkage with\u00a0international markets as a driver for change,\" he said.", "\"So whether there's a single global market that emerges from the COP26 negotiations, or in our view a\u00a0more likely scenario will be a series of bilateral regional arrangements.", "Dr Moore said carbon market arrangements between Australia and Fiji were \"starting to come into play\" and this week\u00a0the federal government announced a carbon market agreement with Papua New Guinea.", "", "
Indigenous ranger groups generate millions of dollars worth of carbon credits each year through fire management.
", "
Credit where credit is\u00a0due
", "Since 2006, Indigenous ranger groups have been earning carbon credits through savanna burning projects across northern Australia.", "According to Indigenous Carbon Industry Network coordinator, Anna Boustead, savanna fire management abates around 1.2 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions each year \u2014 the equivalent of removing nearly 400,000 cars from the road each year.", "\"So, it's fantastic to see the price on the corporate market jump up in recent months,\" she said.", "\"And it means for projects that were marginal under the\u00a0price last year of $16 to $18, they now become more viable.\"", "Ms Boustead said if Indigenous carbon credits could be sold into a global market it would be a 'game-changer'.", "She welcomed the federal government's commitment to net-zero emissions by 2050, but said it was disappointing\u00a0there had been no legislative changes to support the policy.", "\"Our industry has received no new money and\u00a0the government's staggering $20 billion investment of taxpayer funds is clearly targeted at big industry and at technologies such as carbon capture and storage,\" she said.", "\"In their announcement, they simply fail to recognise the benefit of maintaining healthy landscapes and it's very disappointing that\u00a0Minister (Angus Taylor) hasn't backed the very activities that are actually driving down emissions and supporting a whole range of benefits.\"\u00a0"]
